Description: Sherd of Laconian black-figured pottery kylix consisting of part of stem, broad foot and tondo; dull cream slip; interior, in tondo, black-figure decoration consisting of parts of snakes' bodies (or possibly Typhon's body) with added red dots; exterior: glazed black; resting surface of foot reserved; inside of stem glazed; underside of floor reserved with central ring.
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.526.b; 1888,0601.526.e and possibly 1888,0601.526.q. The fragments of the B7.4 cup show a wing and snakes, a combination that makes possible the suggestion that the subject was Typhon, although the work is too fragmentary to allow certain identification. There are some obscure points as well, for example that wings are not a common feature for a sea-daemon. From the little that is left of B7.4, however, a reconstruction is almost impossible, so the question of form and identity must be left open. See Pipili, M., Laconian Iconography of the Sixth Century BC. Oxford 1987, 69. For a wholly preserved example of a "Typhon" see Pipili 1987, 70, fig. 102 (Cerveteri 67658).
